item.title: Carbon Monoxide | Hospitalized elderly due to intoxication
item.description: Health services revealed yesterday that a 79 -year -old man had to receive medical treatment at the Conde de São Januário hospital emergency service after passing out due to carbon monoxide poisoning. The case happened on Sunday afternoon in the Vai Long building (block I), in the Alameda da Tranquility, when the resident was taking a shower in a bathroom where a gas water heater is installed. The resident “began to feel sudden dizziness and eventually fell inanimate on the floor of the bathroom”, where he was found by family members, who immediately called an ambulance. At Conde de São Januário Hospital did laboratory tests, which revealed concentrations of carbon monoxide hemoglobin. The elderly was “undergoing hyperbaric oxygen therapy treatment” and is currently considered stable. Authorities add that the gas water heater has been installed in the bathroom for over a decade, and that despite the installation of a ventilation, the bathroom has no windows. At the time of the occurrence, the exhaust was not connected and the authorities suspect that the incident was caused by the lack of maintenance of the device and the accumulation of residual gas in an environment with poor ventilation.

item.title: Game | JP Morgan indicates improvements in search
item.description:
Despite the most positive trend, JP Morgan admits that compared to February last year there may even be a reduction in gross reciters
After the Lunar New Year, the search for the game in the Macau casinos is "better than the feared." On the other hand, JP Morgan indicates that the weakness of revenues is more related to previous expectations of industry, than actually to the amount generated by the territory tables, which between February 1 and 5 were 900 million patacas per day . Low review The scenario outlined by JP Morgan Post-Anno New Lunar, contrasts with the one that was lived during the festivities and which led another investment bank, Citigroup, to reduce predictions about the expansion of the Macao game this year. item.title: Flu | Another 11 thousand vaccines. Markings open today
item.description:
The significant increase in citizens who want to get the flu vaccine has led health services to buy an additional 11 thousand doses. The markings to take the vaccines have been widened and open today. The government bought 45,000 doses than last year's flu
Following the race for influenza vaccination over the past weekend, taking more than 5,400 residents of health centers and hospitals, the government announced on Monday night that it would buy another 11,000 doses urgently to correspond to demand . Thus, after the arrival last night of the lots, the markings to take the vaccine opened today on the Internet of Health Services website, with the authorities to reach that people over 65 and children between 6 months and 9 years old are exempt from marking. Health services acquired for this time flu (2024/2025) 225 thousand doses of the flu vaccine, an increase of 45 thousand doses in relation (or 25 percent). Until Monday, the authorities accounted for 204,000 doses administered, totaling a 22.2 percent increase over the same period last year, when 167,000 vaccines had been administered. It is recalled that the race for vaccination in the past weekend occurred after two residents died following complications after flu infections A. Macao and the World The government points out that flu vaccination rates this year between risk groups are “ideal” and increased from last year. Among the users of elderly homes, more than 90 percent took the vaccine, while in the infantry the rate exceeds 65 percent, in the kindergartens of primary schools more than 80 percent of children were vaccinated, while in secondary education the rate of inoculation is 70 percent. In the general calculation, among residents over 65 years of age, the vaccination rate is almost 60 percent. The type of vaccines that Macau buys is intended for the northern hemisphere and, as such, their validity expires between May and June of each year. Therefore, the government stresses that "the annual flu vaccination program will end when existing vaccines run out or expire."

item.title: Post Office | Announced Retoma of Service for the USA
item.description:
Macao Post Office resumed sending small packages and orders to the United States, but warned that new suspensions cannot be excluded due to US postal service policies
The Post Office of Macao and Hong Kong announced yesterday the resumption of sending small packages and orders to the United States after five days of suspension. In a statement, the Post Office of Macao (CTT) announced that they will accept again, from February 11, “all mail objects (…) for the United States”. In the same message from the Macao Post and Telecommunications Directorate Directorate, the CTT recalled that the suspension "may have originated a correspondence, which will possibly result in delays in the delivery of shipments to the US." "Additionally, the possibility of any changes in the policies of US postal services [USPS) cannot be excluded at any time," the company warned. The Macao Post Office message was preceded by one of Hong Kong's counterpart, in which they said they had been “formally notified” by the US Postal Service that US authorities “currently do not impose additional fees on postal articles. with commodity ”. On January 5, the company said it had been notified by USPS that it could only send packages or orders that customers had registered with customs and the protection of US borders (CBP). The registration would require “the necessary import documents and the payment of fees made through a customs dispatcher,” added the Hong Kong Post Office. After the suspension of shipping, the company “continued to negotiate” with USPS and “can temporarily resume” the postal service for the United States. Temporary suspensions On February 4, USPS announced that it would temporarily stop accepting orders from China and Hong Kong (without any reference to Macao) “up to new order”. But hours later, USPS reversed the decision without justifying, just stating that it was going to work with the CBP to implement a collection process for the new rates imposed on Chinese goods in order to avoid interruptions in delivery. The new US President Donald Trump increased customs rates on China's imports at 10 percent after retreating in the plans to charge Canada and Mexico. The vast majority of goods sent from China arrive outside the mail system, but Trump's order specifically eliminated a tariff exemption for low -value products, purchased directly by consumers and sent through the postal service. This exemption covered articles of less than US $ 800. The USPS measurement could block or delay orders made through Chinese e -commerce platforms Shein and Temu.

item.title: Study | Reluctant government in legislating vital will
item.description:
A study by Man Teng Iong, professor at the Faculty of Law of the University of Macao, and Vera Lúcia Raposo draws attention to the absence of the “anticipated directive of will”, or vital will, of the legal system of masters. The document allows a person to decide previously whether or not to receive medical treatments in the terminal phase of life
For several years in Portugal any citizen can sign an Early Directive of Will (DAV), also known as the Vital Testament, which allows the conscious decision on the type of medical treatments to receive in a given health context. Being far from constituting a legal form of euthanasia, the document allows to know the patient's will when he, for health reasons, cannot do so. In Macao, the DAV is not legislated and the authorities have revealed signs of reluctance to advance in the process. This is what the study concludes “Advance Directives in Macao: Not Legally Recognissed, but. . . ” [DAV in Macao: No legal recognition, but… ”, signed by Man Teng Iong, professor at the University of Macao Law School (one), and Vera Lúcia Raposo, former director of the same faculty and currently a teacher at the Faculty of Law from the New University of Lisbon. The study was recently published by Cambridge University Press, although it was the theme of Man Teng Iong's master's thesis defended a few years ago. The authors analyze the legal framework of the issue in Macao, concluding that “to date, the Macao Executive assumed a precautionary attitude towards DAV, accepting (or tolerating) these instruments, but not investigating this subject with the necessary force” . "It has been reported that, due to the aging of the population of Macao, and in the light of the adoption of DAV legislation in the last twenty years in countries such as the United States, Australia, Canada and Singapore, the executive recognized the need to legislate DAV." , it is added. The authors indicate that local authorities even recognize the positive factors of accessing this type of legal document. “Such legal instruments will not only increase quality of life and protect patients' dignity at the end of their lives, but also reduce unnecessary medical expenses. On December 3, 2019, Health Services (SS), and the sub -entity of the Life Science Ethics Committee, introduced the 'guidelines and future policy of the DAV' in Macao, agreeing to legitimize [a matter]. However, despite the agreement around the implementation of DAV, the executive insists on maintaining a preliminary discussions around DAV. ” Thus, the authors consider that "hesitation may reflect the fear of the [SS] in facing difficulties and controversies around the plans for its implementation." Consensus as an argument The authors point out that the “barriers to the implementation” of the DAV legal framework in Macao arise “from a low conscience from the public in the face of DAV legislation and the possibility of patients can change the way of facing the end of life, well as the arrangement of the patient's family members to fulfill the patient's wishes ”. The study stresses that the SS have always argued that “an extensive and profound action of sensitization and education with the public has been done in academic, social and legal areas whenever necessary, and that the law that regulates DAV can only be implemented later obtained the consensus of all sectors ”. However, the study states that “it is possible to argue that the position of the executive lacks proper justification”, because “this type of consensus invoked to postpone the regulation of DAV is not possible to achieve, due to the multiplicity of legal, ethical visions and even religious about matter ”. In addition, the authors point out that "even if such a consensus could be achieved, the executive did not take the necessary steps to encourage or facilitate discussion, or awareness, with the population." Data on a study made about the notions of the population of Macao on the subject are referred to, concluding that "the lack of information about the DAV was the main determining factor in the decision of people to make the DAV." "The study also found that 73.6 percent of the sample (724 people) were willing to complete a DAV if the document had legal recognition." Social and political “resistance” Thus, the study's authors warn of the existence of “a great resistance - from certain groups of residents of Macao and the Executive - for the implementation of adequate DAV regulation”. "A possible reason for this hesitation is to the fear that formally legislating DAV can lead to euthanasia, a forbidden practice in Macau, even if the two situations are clearly different," the authors say, who understand to be "imperative that the executive regulates the DAV ”. At this particular point, a new law should “clarify some legal aspects, such as the requirements for the [DAV] and to be legally operational”, ensuring the patient's decision autonomy and ensuring “a more appropriate solution from the point of view human rights ”. The authors draw attention to the influence of Portuguese law of 2012 on the DAV legislation in Macao, drawing attention to the fact that DAV have a greater compatibility with what is currently in the local Civil Code. However, legislating the DAV also causes a cultural discussion, is pointed out. “It is unclear whether DAV regulation would be in agreement with the widespread values ​​of the predominant Chinese community, which still has a great connection to the family. More studies are needed to clarify this and other subjects, since, for example, there are no data on numbers estimates and implementation of DAV in the jurisdiction of Macao ”, and there is“ an urgent need for further investigations that exploit perspectives of the doctors around the DAV ”. The case of the Kiang Wu Hospital, which at the “The Hospice & Palliative Care Center” palliative care center provides treatment for cancer terminal patients. However, before the admission of these patients, the signing of the document “Consent for the Hospice & Palliative Care Center” is required, a kind of consent that is mostly signed by family members and not by the patient himself. In addition, "it is not an authorization document by patients, or not, of medical procedures, but an acceptance of hospital terms and conditions." What current law allows In general terms, DAV in Macau have some legal framework, namely in the Civil Code, although they are not legislated with their own law. The authors conclude, however, that "there is some uncertainty about to what extent DAV would be effective, in particular given that doctors tend to reject any document that rejects a support and life maintenance treatment." “In Macau the discussion around the DAV is almost nonexistent. Without a clear and transparent debate that includes specialists and studies with legal arguments, there will be no legal developments related to the nature, content and use of DAV in the near future, ”he describes.

item.title: Book dedicated to Carlos Paredes includes unpublished recording of show
item.description: The life and work of guitar master Carlos Paredes, who “created a genuinely Portuguese song out of nowhere”, is told in a book to be presented this week in Portugal and which includes the recordings of two concerts, one of which is unprecedented. In “Carlos Paredes - the guitar of a people”, the researcher Octávio Fonseca begins to tell the guitarist's route before he was born, reminiscent of his family background. Carlos Paredes, who would complete a hundred years of life on February 16, descend from a family of guitarists and composers: great-grandfather António Rodrigues Paredes, grandfather Gonçalo Rodrigues Paredes, grand-uncle Manuel Rodrigues Paredes and father, Artur Paredes. According to Octávio Fonseca, Artur Paredes, “in terms of technique, completely revolutionized the guitar of Coimbra”, and Carlos Paredes “took advantage of this work and simplified it”. To tell the story and stories of Carlos Paredes, Octávio Fonseca resorted to the research work he had done to another book dedicated to the guitarist edited in 2000, which included reading articles on music that 'master' wrote in newspapers and interviews that gave to various media. But to write this book, she had "the extraordinary collaboration" of guitarist and songwriter Luísa Amaro, companion of Paredes. "Most of the stories that are told in the book were she who conveyed to me," he said. What makes Carlos Paredes a unique artist is, for Octavio Fonseca, the fact that he created “genuinely Portuguese music of nowhere”. “In the late 1960s, early 1970s, we were very discussing to go to traditional roots, to create a Portuguese popular music, as José Afonso did. But Carlos Paredes did not do that, and created a Portuguese song out of nowhere. He did not start from our traditional song, nor from any experience of Portuguese music, ”said the researcher. The parallelism between José Afonso and Carlos Paredes was pointed out by the guitarist himself. “He says in two interviews that there is a parallel between him and José Afonso at the beginning of his career. Carlos Paredes's first album is from 1962 and José Afonso's first ballad album as well (he had albums before, but it was from Fado de Coimbra). They both make a new song from Coimbra, ”he said. The following year, the two musicians “break free from Coimbra, from the song of Coimbra”, but with a difference, “while with José Afonso there is a complete cut, with Carlos Paredes there is a cut, but there are always a 'penguinhos' in the compositions in which Coimbra appears ”. MUSICAL NEWS “Carlos Paredes - the guitar of a people” is accompanied by two records. One is “Master of the Portuguese Guitar”, an album recorded in 1977, at the 7th Political Song Festival in Berlin, edited this year by her friend, editor of the former German Democratic Republic (RDA), which is unprecedented in Portugal. In the other album is recorded “The First Show Carlos Paredes made in his own name in Portugal”, an unprecedented recording registered on March 31, 1984, at the Carlos Alberto Theater, in Porto. The book also includes a photo portfolio by Carlos Paredes, by Augusto Cabrita, Luís Paulo Moura and Inácio Ludgero. The musician lived mainly in Lisbon and the city inspired many of his compositions. “Green Years”, one of the best known of his work, was composed for the homonymous film of Paulo Rocha, milestone of the new Portuguese cinema of the 1960s. Anti-fascist combatant, opposed the dictatorship and was arrested by PIDE in the late 1950s. Until the 1990s, it reconciled the guitar with its administrative activity at the São José Hospital in Lisbon. In December 1993, he was diagnosed with myelopathy, a disease that attacked him the bone structure and that prevented him from playing guitar.

item.title: USA | Pyongyang denounces “hostile military act”
item.description: North Korea accused the United States on Monday of committing a "hostile military act," after a US Navy submarine has moved in South Korea for refueling. "We are very concerned about the dangerous hostile military act of the United States, which can lead the acute military confrontation in the region of the Korean Peninsula to a total armed conflict," said a spokesman for the Ministry of Defense, quoted in a statement released by the agency of State News KCNA. Pyongyang has asked the United States to "stop the provocations that feed instability," accusing them of ignoring North Korean security concerns. South Korea Yonhap news agency said USS Alexandria, a US nuclear submarine, arrived on Monday on Busan, South Korea on Monday. A similar visit had occurred in November. "Our Armed Forces are closely monitoring the frequent appearance of US strategic assets on the Korean Peninsula and are ready to use all means to defend state security and interests, as well as regional peace," said the port -Voice of the Ministry of Defense of North Korea. North Korea emphasized the importance of developing its self -defense capabilities and referred to the promise of leader Kim Jong Un in January to continue his country's nuclear program "indefinitely." Good old friends United States President Donald Trump expressed on Friday the intention to build bridges with Kim Jong-un's North Korean regime. “I think it's a great advantage for everyone that I get along with him. I like him, I mean, I get along with him, he gets along with me. And that's a good thing, it's not a bad thing, ”said the Republican. But North Korea replied that the nuclear weapons it possesses are not a bargaining chip to negotiate, but a force to stop threats, and justified the reinforcement of weapons with the geopolitical aspirations of the West. The statement suggests that Pyongyang has no interest in returning to the negotiating table with Washington. In the first term as president of the United States, Donald Trump proposed to North Korea to end nuclear weapons in exchange for support in economic development. The North Korean message also mentioned the recent statements of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and the European Union, which reaffirmed that they will not recognize North Korea as nuclear power. Pyongyang accuses the West of being a destabilizing force of peace. item.title: CPSP | Reinforced prevention in combating human trafficking
item.description: The Public Security Police Corps (CPSP) ensures that it has reinforced prevention in combating human trafficking after in late December revealed that five residents of Macao were victims of human trafficking and forced to “work” on online fraud centers in Taiwan and Cambodia. In response to questions posed by Macau News Agency, police authorities indicate having published on social networks messages warning of cases of people who are seduced with work proposals in Southeast Asia, but eventually fall into meshes of criminal groups that are dedicated to online fraud. The victims, in their wide Chinese majority, are forced to defraud people in telecommunications centers. Although they do not reveal whether there have been additional cases of Macao residents beyond the five announced in December, CPSP indicates that the objective of the prevention campaign has alerted the population to be cautious when they are offered a job through online platforms or people Unknown, especially when these jobs imply trips abroad. Another sign of danger covers the form of work that promises high wages, without the need for academic background, technical capacity or work experience in the area.

However, “music” (樂/乐 yuè) is so important to the Chinese that their synogram is confused in the written form with that of “joy” (樂/乐 lè). From an etymological point of view, it is the pictogram of a musical instrument, whose base represents the wood part and the top the strings of it. This, for the satisfaction that raises when it is touched, will serve by extension of meaning to figure the synogram of joy. Music before belonging to humanity, depends on the deities of the Chinese popular animist religion and natural forces such as wind or biological beings such as birds, or mythological like fenices. It is known that the yellow emperor (黄帝 Huángdì) ruled in a mythical antiquity that dates back to organized Chinese civilization. But this, according to one of the great Taoist philosophers of Chinese antiquity, Lie Yukou (列御寇 Liè Yùkòu ”) in the homonymous work Liezi (列子“ Lièzǐ ·) puts the emperor to make spiritual trips in which he finds feminine deities of matriarchal times, as Huaxu (華胥/华胥 Huáxū), mother of the first Chinese Emperor Fuxi (伏羲 Fuxī) and, therefore, ancestral matriarch of all Chinese or even the mother and/or mysterious woman of the ninth sky (九天聖 (圣) 母/九天玄女 jiǔtān shèngmǔ/jiiǔtān xuannǚ), which will have taught him a lot, even in the case of the latter to appreciate music, poetry, and was also started by her, who had a human face and body of phoenix, in the arts of love. As for Phoenix is ​​the bird that symbolizes eternal life and peace; When the gray itself is reborn, it transports the hope of whole, renewed and peaceful beings, as it only arises in the world in times of tranquility and harmony. But it is also in close relationship with the music, because it is a mythological bird that sings, such as the wind, whose sound is composed for the Chinese by the melodious beating of the wings of the birds, when it comes to breeze, or the beating of the same in storm. Linglun (伶倫/伶伦 Ling Lun) created the twelve shades following a request from the yellow emperor, which after being properly polite and trained his musical ear for the mysterious woman of ninth sky, was bored in the trips of inspection by Earth with The monotony of melodies. This great musician rushed to fulfill orders and surrendered with soul and heart to listen to all the sounds of nature to obtain the required inspiration to the mission. But it was in the Kunlun Sacred Mountain (崑崙山/昆仑山 Kūnlún Shān) that he obtained the lighting necessary for the creation of twelve tones by resorting to twelve bamboo tubes. How did he verify the right tones? “Loading the twelve bamboo tubes, Linglun reached the foot of the Kunlun mountain to hear the song of the Phoenix. When the birds sang, the male gave six shouts and the female answered them with six others. Linglun compared the twelve screams with his sounds and found that there was a perfect match between them. ” (Wang and Alves, 2009, 48) He had reached his goal. The shades followed the model of the Phoenices, when he presented his creation to the Yellow Emperor, having been precisely rewarded with the title of God of Music [音樂 (乐) 之神 Yīnyuè Zhī Shén] and the world has since filled with More beautiful melodies. Going now to philosophy, the cosmos faced as a mysterious musical instrument is one of the favorite metaphors of one of the great Taoist philosophers, the prince of Huainan, Liu an [劉 (刘) 安 Liú'ān, 179? -122 BC] It leaves us a work of the early days of the Han Dynasty, entitled Huainanzi (《淮南子》 Huáinánzǐ). The work is known in the Chinese tradition also with the title of (《淮南子鴻烈》 Huáinánzǐ Hóngliè), whose meaning is “the radiant light of Master Huainan”, having been the sixth chapter translated by Canadian synologist Charles Le Blanc, under the Title Huainanzi 淮南子 Philosophical Synthesis in Early Han Thought, containing the suggestive subtitle The Idea of ​​Resonance (Kan-Ying 感應) with a Translation and Analysis of Chapter Six. Suppose that the whole universe is linked, in the manner of the ropes of an instrument, spreading the sound, echoing and resonating when it touches on a ropes, will have its western counterpart in the mysticism of the Pythagorean pre-Socratic philosopher and its assumption of the “music of the spheres”, that is, the melody produced by the stars in their heavenly trajectories. Returning to the Master of Huainan, he is informed in section II of the IX of the sixth chapter, that “the mutual response of things belonging to the same category is deeply mysterious and extremely subtle” (BLANC, 1985, 116), to which the text corresponds to the text Original is in Appendix 1 (Blanc, 1985, 221-215): “夫物類之相應玄妙深微知不能論” (6/ 3a.5) 2. item.title: Artificial Intelligence | Study highlights China's leadership goal
item.description:
China aims to lead the global market of artificial intelligence, “both in terms of theory and application”, seeking self-sufficiency in this domain. This is one of the conclusions of Muhammed Can's PhD Thesis, “Artificial Intelligence as a resource: an evaluation of China's mobilization and extraction strategies”, defended at the University of Minho
A few months before the launch of the “DeepSeek” platform in China, which revolutionized the Artificial Intelligence (AI) market in competition with the chatgPT, was defended at the University of Minho (one) a doctoral thesis that precisely concludes, the ones Steps Beijing is taking to look for global leadership in this area. The work, by Muhammed Can, calls “Artificial Intelligence as Resource: An Appraisal of China's Mobilization and Extraction Strategies” [Artificial Intelligence as a resource: an evaluation of China's mobilization and extraction strategies], and analyzes the connection of the He went to international relations, as well as the strategy that the country has adopted in this domain in recent years. The thesis, in the area of ​​political science and international relations, was defended at the school of Economics and Management of UM. Thus, it is concluded that the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) “aims to become the world leader in both theory and AI-applications”, and some main objectives were outlined for “the process of resource mobilization and development AI ”. According to the author, they go through the “search for self-sufficiency, a view of 2015 strategy, 'Made in China 2025 ′”, as well as “economic transformation, with a view to perfectly integrating AI and automation in the national economy perfectly ”. Moreover, the author considers that Beijing seeks to become a competitor and leader in the AI ​​area to combat advances in other markets, namely in the United States, using initiatives such as the “Digital Silk Route of China and definition efforts of patterns as the way for external validation ”. Thus, "China's external resource extraction strategies are facilitated by the various economic mechanisms, aiming at the transfer of knowledge and talent acquisition, with the aim of filling out the resource gap with the United States." The “techno-nationalism” The thesis also speaks of the notion of “techno-nationalism”, linked to the area of ​​international relations, such as “the most important variable in China's AI policy”, and can also “be seen as a continuation and manifestation of the strategy of ' Two markets, two features' of the CCP ”. With this approach, China intends to "protect the domestic market and, simultaneously, expand abroad, promote the sale of products manufactured in China and extract resources such as data, talent, know-how and many others." In addition, “the implications of techno-nationalism also extend to foreign technological companies that operate in China”, since, “in the context of ordinary companies, China uses several barriers and takes advantage of its national legal framework as an instrument for an instrument for the strategic transfer of technology and specialized knowledge ”. Academic work takes into account the policies and laws implemented between 2012 and 2023, concluding that after the launch of the “New Generation Artificial Intelligence Development Plan” [NAIDP, in the English acronym], in 2017, the Chinese strategy for AI Won a new direction. "The thesis shows that the pace to which the resources were mobilized increased sharply after the announcement of NAIDP in 2017", having been revealed a set of "initiatives and plans related to AI, intended for systematic mobilization of essential resources for the development of I was ”. In the years referring to the study, “the CCP has enacted a series of data related policies and laws, including laws related to the privacy of individual data”, introducing “legal frameworks specifically related to national security, which have direct implications for governance and data regulation ”. The author also describes the way Beijing has adopted to mobilize all resources available around AI policy, with the Council of State “promulgating comprehensive strategic plans pertinent to AI or AI -related matters - such as the action plan Triennial Internet + Artificial Intelligence ”. It is these documents that will “articulate short and long term goals and standards, serving as a course for a coordinated development in this field”. Essential resources in developing AI projects and policies are “data, algorithms and computing capacity”. It should be noted that there is a “CCP resource mobilization strategy” that has the “approach of 'whole society' and 'whole government'”. Such "implies that all segments of society, including government institutions, private companies and individuals, may be involved in AI development effort if it is considered necessary." It is, according to the thesis, "an integrated approach that allows a more cohesive and comprehensive strategy for the mobilization of resources in the context of AI development." After “the introduction of global strategies”, the CCP “begins the process of mobilization of resources through designated government institutions”, namely ministries, the AI ​​promotion office and the China Cyberspace administration ”. “To improve its resource mobilization strategy, the CCP actively incorporates private actors in the AI ​​development ecosystem. By designating certain large technological companies such as AI national champions, the government not only mobilizes these companies, but also encourages them to mobilize more resources according to the state's strategic objectives ”, it reads. Importance of local governments Like in other fields, China realized early on that AI was an important area to invest and would have to be part of economic and political strategies. Thus, Muhammed Can's thesis "demonstrates that CCP changes in technological policy are closely aligned with the strategic environment," as the party "has realized opportunities and threats in significant global developments." Still regarding the mobilization of resources for the development of AI, the author speaks of a process “complex and distributed instead of a singular approach, from top to bottom, led only by the CCP or the State Council”. “Although the CCP establishes the general rules and guidelines, it actively involves a wide range of stakeholders - including companies, universities and ministerial bodies - in the mobilization process. This distributed strategy can be understood in the context of China's size, both in terms of population and geographical extension, which requires a more dispersed approach. ” The author highlights the “preponderant role that local governments play in the development of AI” because “they function as extensions of the central authority, and their active involvement implies direct mobilization of resources”, namely at the level of algorithms and computing capacity. "The thesis concludes that local governments have also instituted various strategies to improve policies associated with data, algorithms and computing capacity," can be read. “Some local governments took the initiative to formulate their own AI strategies before the central authorities issued official guidelines. Subsequently, these local strategies were reviewed to conform to the central directives. ” To analyze local AI policies, the author analyzed the cases of Shanghai and Shenzhen. Moreover, the idea of ​​mobilization around the AI ​​area is attached with historical issues, as Beijing has always sought the avant-garde in the technology area, namely since the Cold War times. As read in the thesis, “China began to rely heavily on exported technology from the Soviet Union after the creation of the Popular Republic of China”, but “the restrictive strategic environment began to evolve with the historic visit of US President Richard Nixon , in 1972 ”, having represented" an invaluable opportunity for China and the US counterbalances the Soviet threat. " Thanks to archive research, the author concludes that "China's strategic environment has moved to a partially permissive state around 1978, coinciding with the beginning of the reform and opening policies of leader Deng Xiaoping." From this year onwards, “a dramatic expansion of opportunities for the CCP in the field of technological development”. In general terms, "the concept of mobilization is intrinsically linked to the longtime vanguard role of the CCP, a role that facilitated the rapid mobilization of resources during key moments of its history." Not on purpose, China has participated since yesterday at the Summit about AI that takes place in Paris, the AI ​​action summit, having sent Deputy Prime Minister Zhang Quoqing. In this summit, which ends today, “heads of state, researchers and technology companies that will discuss how governments should respond to rapid advances in this domain are present,” according to Lusa.

item.title: Tourism | Analysis says that Macau is increasingly a leisure destination
item.description:
The academics Pedro Steenhagen and Sofia Xiaoying have analyzed the Macao Tourism Industry, concluding that, increasingly, the territory is viewed as a leisure destination and not as much as a gaming land. The authors warn of the “long way to go regarding the promotion of sustainable tourism”
The Macao Tourism sector has changed in recent years and the visions of the tourists themselves as well, facing the territory as a place where one can walk and enjoy leisure zones, not as much as a game land. This is one of the conclusions of the “Tourism as A Driver of China's Cultural Soft Power: The Role of Macau and the Convergences Between The New Silk Road and the Greater Bay Area” [Tourism as the engine of China's Soft Power: The Role From Macao and the convergences between the new silk route and the Great Bay area], by Pedro Steenhagen, Fudan University, and Sofia Xiaoying Hou, linked to the Xi'an University of International Studies. Analysis of the tourism industry at MSAR is one of the chapters of the book “The Palgrave Handbook on China-Europe-Africa Relations”, recently edited. Thus, it is concluded that “the perception of the image of Macau by tourists has been changing in the last 10 years, being the more and more seen as a place of leisure and vacation in general, and not specifically or purely as a game center. ” It is also added that “the image of masters as a tourist destination is in transition, and people visiting Macao have greatly valued their unique cultural attractions, including their architecture and gastronomy, the result of the mixture of Chinese and Portuguese cultures and inheritances” . However, the authors consider that "Macau still has a long way to go regarding the promotion of effective sustainable tourism." It is understood that sustainable tourism “must fully take into account its economic, social and environmental impacts, addressing the needs of visitors, sector, environment and related communities”. In this field, the authors highlight, quoting another author, that "Macau has made efforts to achieve good grades in these and other subjects, because the rider tourism industry has been undergoing a" silent revolution "since the beginning of the pandemic." It is also noteworthy that, worldwide, the International Tourism Organization has created some guidelines on sustainability, creating “an important framework of sustainable tourism”. For this, “five fundamental pillars were proposed to evaluate the sustainability of the tourism sector of a state”, such as “tourism policy and governance; trade, investment, data and competitiveness; Employment, decent work and training; Reduction of poverty and social inclusion; and sustainability of natural and cultural environments ”. The Silk Route The academics also analyze the role of the Macao tourist sector in the strategy of “a track, a route”, noting that the territory “has been gaining a prominent role in local, regional and external policies, being an actor capable of improving the Tourism Silk Route and streamline tourism in the Great Bay region ”. Macau is understood to make new contributions to the way China presents its culture, because “due to existing heritage and tourist products, it presents the Chinese culture to foreign visitors through a new, more diverse lens that goes beyond traditional” . Thus, tourists are allowed, “especially in the Lusophone world, [create] a better connection and understanding of the country through common historical and cultural bonds”. With regard to the Great Bay project, it is also considered that both this region and the territory of Macao have “actively integrated the tourism development strategies in the BRI frame”, ie “Belt and Road Initiative”, English designation for “a track, a route”. Macao has “a diverse and distinct range of tourist resources, such as the arts, history, constructions and religious traditions, gastronomy, sport, museums, among others”, and local authorities have sought, according to the authors, “Mark its tourist industry, promoting 'Tourism+' with transfronic cooperation in the scope of bri”. The idea is to “create an image of Macau as a city with diverse cultures, integrating the sectors of tourism, entertainment, culture, sports, business, conventions and exhibitions, health care, recreation, technology and big events”. IMPROVEMENTS ON COURSE Pedro Steenhagen and Sofia Xiaoying Hou understand that the Macao government “has been trying to improve cultural soft power and increase tourist attractiveness through product development, facilities and advertising improvement”, and “projects to improve Facilities such as hotels, restaurants, transport and digital tours. ” The example of two digital pathways created by the Cultural Institute, namely, in 2021, “The House of the Family of Zheng Guanying” and also “Fortaleza da Guia”. Moreover, authorities have created several interactive platforms using increased virtual reality. Despite all the efforts pointed out to the local authorities, it is understood that "masters still have an unexplored potential to reinforce cultural ties between China and Portuguese-speaking countries, and this decade may present great opportunities in this regard." The tourist bet In this chapter, the authors also look at the positioning of tourism in the initiative “a track, a route” by Beijing, given that “China has been increasingly paying attention to the need to expand its cultural soft power , both regional and global. ” Thus, the country "has formulated several cultural development plans associated with" a track, a route "and the area of ​​the great bay, and tourism has constantly appeared as an essential element of its global strategy.” In the country "tourism has gained relevance, either as a means of improving international image and as a source of revenue." Only in 2018 “about 159 million visitors traveled to the country, which invested $ 155 billion in tourist infrastructure-a value behind the United States, but should become the first by 2028- since you saw the sector represents 11 percent of your total gross domestic product. ” The authors argue that “by connecting and increasing the dynamics between BRI [Belt and Road Initiative] and the Great Bay area, with an interesting effort on the diversification of Macao's economy and strengthening its tourist sector, as well as among the objectives. National and regional, China seems to be finding a way to boost tourism and reap the fruits in terms of cultural soft power. ” Thus, and in the long run, it is considered that the country “may not only grow the power of its narratives and culture, but also improve normative power and institutional positioning in the world scene, especially with regard to issues of governance ”. It should be noted that the book “The Palgrave Handbook on China-Europe-Africa Relations” is edited by Yichao Li, Jorge Tavares da Silva, Carlos Rodrigues and Francisco José Leandro, from the University of Macau. The edition is in charge of Palgrave Macmillan.

item.title: Portuguese | Study points to Brazil's lack of focus in Macau and China
item.description:
“Brazilian Foreign Policy and the Quest to Promote Portuguese: Building Bridges Through Macau”, a study by João Simões, from the City of Macau, and Daniel Veras, draws attention to the need for Brazil to bet more on the advantages of Macau in the promotion of Portuguese, as well as in China
A study recently published in Janus magazine, from the Autonomous University of Lisbon, draws attention to the fact that Brazil is not properly enjoying the advantages that Macau can offer in the promotion of the Portuguese language, integrated into the country's foreign policy. “Brazilian Foreign Policy and the Quest to Promote Portuguese: Building Bridges Through Macau” [Brazilian foreign policy and the issue of Portuguese promotion: building bridges through Macau] is authored by João Simões, assistant professor at the City of Macau (UCM ) and Daniel Veras, professor at the Pontifical Catholic University of Minas Gerais, in Brazil. “It is time for Brazil to have a more significant presence in Macao, not only through diplomatic channels, but also encouraging the involvement of several non -state actors, such as commerce and investment chambers, professional associations, Brazilian cultural centers, media organs , artistic and cultural foundations, among others ”, read in the article. Thus, the authors consider that this set of partners could help Brazil “leverage the role of Macau as a generator of opportunities, something Brazil has not yet fully enjoyed”, since this “reinforced presence in Macau would allow the consolidation of Existing partnerships between Brazilian universities and mainland China ”. In addition, at the level of students, a more robust presence in Brazil in the MSAR could “bring Chinese students closer to Portuguese from Brazilian companies, reinforcing the connection between education and the business ecosystem of the great bay”, as well as to enhance the production of "Locally adapted didactic materials to the Chinese context and, ultimately, bringing Brazil and China closer to the unique environment that Macau offers." Based on official documents and other studies on this theme, the authors consider that, in general terms, there is “the need for Brazil effectively to take advantage of Macau's strategic position to capitalize on these opportunities”. Noteworthy among the main points of this position is the fact that, in Macao, the policy of “a country, two systems”, being “an International Porto, an autonomous customs zone” and having “a simple and reduced tax regime”, is noted among Macao. , without forgetting the role of commercial platform. Academics also refer to the “Development Plan for Proper Economic Diversification of MSAR (2024-2028)” which “also offers opportunities, especially the promotion of key industries such as traditional Chinese medicine, the modern financial industry, state -of -the -art technology and MICE (meetings, incentives, conferences and exhibitions) and culture and sports. A weak bet Regarding China, Brazil is also not exploring every opportunity, João Simões and Daniel Veras highlight. "Brazil's foreign policy has actively promoted the Portuguese language in certain geographies, but has not given priority to China, despite the importance of the bilateral relationship between the two countries." It is stated that “the Portuguese language is expanding in China, but Brazil's participation is not up to its magnitude as the largest Portuguese-speaking country in the world”. It is argued that this “discrepancy is even more surprising if we consider that China has been Brazil's largest commercial partner since 2009”. The study highlights Victoria Almeida's position on the origin of Portuguese teachers in China, which “historically the teaching of Portuguese in China was referenced teachers from Portugal”. Thus, “only recently teachers in Brazil became more predominant”, and one of the explanations pointed out to this is the creation of the reader program, which sends teachers to teach Portuguese worldwide. The situation of this program is mentioned in 2010, when "13 readers were selected, two of which placed in China: one in Bisu and one at Guangdong University of Foreign Studies." Still, "Brazil's didactic materials are scarce, and although there are Chinese students who want to go to Brazil, these opportunities are limited and the costs are high." It is understood that Brazil “could take advantage of what is happening with the teaching of Portuguese in mainland China”, because “after years of rapid growth in the number of Portuguese apprentices, we are now in an investment phase in the so-called area studies. or regional ”. Thus, “Brazilian higher education and research institutions can contribute to the reinforcement of China's area studies on Lusophone and Latin America countries, through the investigation and analysis of social, economic, political and cultural dynamics of the target regions ”, Especially given the initiative“ a track, a route ”, is stressed by the authors. Portugal does better The study denotes that, despite the various exchanges between Brazilian and Chinese higher education, the truth is that “many more Chinese students return from exchanges in Portugal, whose best universities offer exchanges with Chinese students”, considering that “it will take a long time until that Brazil builds a teaching culture in China ”. Thus, “compared to Brazil, Portugal has a greater framing in the teaching of Portuguese abroad”, providing “Teaching Programs and Scholarships for Chinese Students”, Master's and PhD level, without forgetting “Partnership with the Camões Institute ”. “Portugal also facilitates the acquisition of titles, as well as promoting the translation of Portuguese novels in China. On the other hand, Brazil does not make such a structured effort. As a result, currently, most Chinese Portuguese-speaking students tend to use European Portuguese as a base or at least as a reference, ”he says. Thus, João Simões and Daniel Veras consider that “Brazil can capitalize on the current context, which encompasses several favorable factors, to adopt a more collaborative approach to the promotion of Portuguese language in China”. The study states that, currently, Portuguese is spoken by more than 264 million people on five continents, and this number is expected to rise to nearly 400 million people in 2050, with “the African continent responsible for the largest increase”, reinforcing The preponderance of Portuguese as one of the most spoken languages ​​in the southern hemisphere. In addition, Portuguese is an official or work language in 32 international organizations. With the arrival of Lula da Silva to the presidency of Brazil for the second time, the authors consider that he “has tried an approach to China”, namely in the commitment to join the initiative “a track, a route” and the appointment “of a representative permanent at the Macao Forum ”. The academics cite another author's idea regarding the existence of “distrust and reserve that Brazil has shown over the years in relation to the Macao Forum”. Greater involvement “can help to guarantee China access to vital resources and markets in Brazil and Africa, potentially contributing to China's food and internal energy security” as well as enhancing Macau as a “cultural channel between China and the World Lusophone ”. However, “although there is political will and a favorable environment in Macao, more concerted efforts will be needed by Brazil to materialize these opportunities,” is mentioned.

item.title: Study | Reluctant government in legislating vital will
item.description:
A study by Man Teng Iong, professor at the Faculty of Law of the University of Macao, and Vera Lúcia Raposo draws attention to the absence of the “anticipated directive of will”, or vital will, of the legal system of masters. The document allows a person to decide previously whether or not to receive medical treatments in the terminal phase of life
For several years in Portugal any citizen can sign an Early Directive of Will (DAV), also known as the Vital Testament, which allows the conscious decision on the type of medical treatments to receive in a given health context. Being far from constituting a legal form of euthanasia, the document allows to know the patient's will when he, for health reasons, cannot do so. In Macao, the DAV is not legislated and the authorities have revealed signs of reluctance to advance in the process. This is what the study concludes “Advance Directives in Macao: Not Legally Recognissed, but. . . ” [DAV in Macao: No legal recognition, but… ”, signed by Man Teng Iong, professor at the University of Macao Law School (one), and Vera Lúcia Raposo, former director of the same faculty and currently a teacher at the Faculty of Law from the New University of Lisbon. The study was recently published by Cambridge University Press, although it was the theme of Man Teng Iong's master's thesis defended a few years ago. The authors analyze the legal framework of the issue in Macao, concluding that “to date, the Macao Executive assumed a precautionary attitude towards the DAV, accepting (or tolerating) these instruments, but not investigating this subject with the necessary force” . "It has been reported that, due to the aging of the population of Macao, and in the light of the adoption of DAV legislation in the last twenty years in countries such as the United States, Australia, Canada and Singapore, the executive recognized the need to legislate DAV." , it is added. The authors indicate that local authorities even recognize the positive factors of accessing this type of legal document. “Such legal instruments will not only increase quality of life and protect patients' dignity at the end of their lives, but also reduce unnecessary medical expenses. On December 3, 2019, Health Services (SS), and the sub -entity of the Life Science Ethics Committee, introduced the 'guidelines and future policy of the DAV' in Macao, agreeing to legitimize [a matter]. However, despite the agreement around the implementation of DAV, the executive insists on maintaining a preliminary discussions around DAV. ” Thus, the authors consider that "hesitation may reflect the fear of the [SS] in facing difficulties and controversies around the plans for its implementation." Consensus as an argument The authors point out that the “barriers to the implementation” of the DAV legal framework in Macao arise “from a low conscience from the public in the face of DAV legislation and the possibility of patients can change the way of facing the end of life, well as the arrangement of the patient's family members to fulfill the patient's wishes ”. The study points out that the SS have always argued that “an extensive and profound action of sensitization and education has been done with the public, in academic, social and legal areas whenever necessary, and that the law that regulates DAV can only be implemented later obtained the consensus of all sectors ”. However, the study states that “it is possible to argue that the position of the executive lacks proper justification”, because “this type of consensus invoked to postpone the regulation of DAV is not possible to achieve, due to the multiplicity of legal, ethical visions and even religious about matter ”. In addition, the authors point out that "even if such a consensus could be achieved, the executive did not take the necessary steps to encourage or facilitate discussion, or awareness, with the population." Data on a study made about the notions of the population of Macao on the subject are referred to, concluding that "the lack of information about the DAV was the main determining factor in the decision of people to make the DAV." "The study also found that 73.6 percent of the sample (724 people) were willing to complete a DAV if the document had legal recognition." Social and political “resistance” Thus, the study's authors warn of the existence of “a great resistance - from certain groups of residents of Macao and the Executive - for the implementation of adequate DAV regulation”. "A possible reason for this hesitation is to the fear that formally legislating DAV can lead to euthanasia, a forbidden practice in Macau, even if the two situations are clearly different," the authors say, who understand to be "imperative that the executive regulates the DAV ”. At this specific point, a new law should “clarify some legal aspects, such as the requirements for the [DAV] and to be legally operational”, ensuring the patient's decision autonomy and ensuring “a more appropriate solution from the point of view of the point of view human rights ”. The authors draw attention to the influence of Portuguese law of 2012 on the DAV legislation in Macao, drawing attention to the fact that DAV have a greater compatibility with what is currently in the local Civil Code. However, legislating the DAV also causes a cultural discussion, is pointed out. “It is unclear whether DAV regulation would be in agreement with the widespread values ​​of the predominant Chinese community, which still has a great connection to the family. More studies are needed to clarify this and other subjects, since, for example, there are no data on numbers estimates and implementation of DAV in the jurisdiction of Macao ”, and there is“ an urgent need for further investigations that exploit perspectives of the doctors around the DAV ”. The case of the Kiang Wu Hospital, which at the “The Hospice & Palliative Care Center” palliative care center provides treatment for cancer terminal patients. However, before the admission of these patients, the signing of the document “Consent for the Hospice & Palliative Care Center” is required, a kind of consent that is mostly signed by family members and not by the patient himself. In addition, "it is not an authorization document by patients, or not, of medical procedures, but an acceptance of hospital terms and conditions." What current law allows In general terms, DAV in Macau have some legal framework, namely in the Civil Code, although they are not legislated with their own law. The authors conclude, however, that "there is some uncertainty about to what extent DAV would be effective, in particular given that doctors tend to reject any document that rejects a support and life maintenance treatment." “In Macau the discussion around the DAV is almost nonexistent. Without a clear and transparent debate that includes specialists and studies with legal arguments, there will be no legal developments related to the nature, content and use of DAV in the near future, ”he describes.

item.title: Chinese New Year | Tourism and trips boosted consumption
item.description:
Arrived to the end of Chinese New Year's holidays, official numbers do not lie: China has crossed an intense consumption period, especially related to travel and tourism. Between January 28 and this Tuesday, some destinations in the country broke records of visitors
It is at the beginning of each year that the economy expects the one of the high moments for tourism and consumption in China. The Chinese New Year represents not only a moment of family life, but also the opportunity for many Chinese to travel. This year, to celebrate the year of the serpent, millions of people traveled internally and also out of the country between January 28 and Tuesday, and according to Xinhua the numbers are impressive with regard to purchases or number of visitors in some Destinations. The Altay City Hall, in the Xinjiang Autonomous Region, is referred to as one of the great ski destinations in the country, having received between January 28 and 31 191,900 visitors, a tourist flow that generated 225 million yuan in revenues. The agency points out that "skiing has definitely became the most popular activity in Altay during the holidays," leading to "a record number of practitioners, more than 10,000, to visit Jiangjunshan's ski resort on February 2". This represented "an increase of 23 percent over the previous year." The Altay zone is famous for registering between 170 and 180 days of snow per year, and in the mountainous areas the average snow depth reaches between one and two meters. Another region of China that reached considerable numbers on the Chinese New Year holidays was Yangshuo County in the Autonomous Guangxi Zhuang region, thanks "to unique natural landscapes and rich cultural activities." Between January 28 and 30, this area received about 410,600 tourists, generating tourist revenues of 589 million Yuan. In turn, Lhasa (in Tibet) also registered an increase in the number of visitors. Between January 28 and Monday, the city received 1.95 million tourists, representing an increase of 20.6 percent over the previous year, and found in tourist revenues almost 1.76 billion Yuan. This is an increase of 14.75 percent compared to the previous year, according to the Lhasa Municipal Culture and Tourism Office. Positive data from agencies Also according to Xinhua, the Chinese New Year's numbers also revealed themselves on travel reserve platforms. In the case of Fliggy, one of the main online agencies, "an increase in reserves, especially for cities such as Shanghai, Beijing and Guangzhou" was recorded. On the other hand, "international travel orders have increased significantly, with international cruise reserves increasing more than six times compared to the previous year." Regarding air traffic, Shanghai Airport Group reported that passenger traffic on Sunday has reached a new historic record of 404,000 people, with Pudong Airport in Shanghai, to record 259,000 passengers and Hongqiao Airport 145,000 passengers. There was also a “reinforced coordination of the services of metro, buses and taxis to ensure transport without problems” with the arrival of the end of the holidays, said the group. On Monday, China State Railway Group Co., Ltd. recorded “a historic milestone” as they were transported on all railways a total of 16.45 million people. This is the “largest passenger traffic in a single day in the history of the Spring Festival Race”. Only this Tuesday, the last day of the holidays, will have traveled 16.9 million passengers, a number that highlights “even more the peak of travel, since hundreds of millions of people returned to their destinations after family meetings” . Comes and Babies As far as tourism is concerned, it was found “a growing number of people who sought to know the heritage of China, motivated by the registration of the Spring Festival in the representative list of UNESCO's Immaterial Cultural Heritage, in December 2024”, indicates the state agency. Data from the Ministry of Commerce show that sales in major retail and restoration companies throughout China, during the first four days of holidays, increased 5.4 percent compared to the same period last year. There was an increase in consumption of imported food and drinks, such as lobsters, beer and wine. "Due to increased demand during the Spring Festival, our company's imports increased almost 50 percent last month," said Yang Xinyu, who represents a company in the Guangzhou -based international supply chain. Since January that the customs authorities of Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport have enlarged the importation of food and crab products, 31.8 percent compared to 2024, translated the total of 14.3 million Yuan. Many online shopping And if the Chinese New Year is synonymous with family reunion, the holidays were once again a time for online shopping. Meituan, one of the country's leading electronic service platforms, has recorded an “impressive increase” of 300 percent over the previous year in online reserves for Lunar New Year's Eve. It should be noted that “group orders for packages with the theme 'intangible cultural heritage' have increased more than 12 times since January, year after year, reflecting the growing interest of consumers in cultural experiences.” Sun Jiashan, an associate researcher at the Central Academy of Culture and Tourism Administration, said, according to Xinhua, a change in consumer behavior, especially by young people and families. "Young families are increasingly becoming the driving force of consumption, with a tendency for diverse, high quality and culturally rich experiences," he said. Meituan Travel data corroborates the analyst's observation that young people increasingly choose to celebrate the Spring Festival in smaller cities, plunging into intangible cultural heritage and historical landmarks. The increase in tourism and cultural consumption, from equity experiences to successful films, indicate a growing demand for traditional and contemporary cultural activities. "This trend has also led to increased demand for cultural and tourist products and services, giving rise to the introduction of new models and business formats that adapt better to contemporary cultural consumption standards," Sun said, highlighting the potential of the Chinese consumer market and the internal driving forces of the economy. But not only shopping was made this Chinese New Year, as "the country's film industry proved to be one of the biggest winners during the spring festival's consumer wave." Between January 29 and February 3, the ticket daily revenues exceeded billion yuan for six consecutive days, raising the ticket offices of this year's Spring Festival to 8.02 billion yuans, According to China's movie administration data, China's total box office on this year's holidays, including real-time pre-sale, exceeded ten billion Yuan.

item.title: Denmark | PM Refusal Sell Grolândia
item.description: Denmark Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen was yesterday available to dialogue with the United States over Granelândia, stressing that the autonomous territory “is not for sale”. "We have been very clear: we all have to respect the sovereignty of all states in the world - and Granelândia is today a part of the Denmark Kingdom - it is not on sale," he said. The Danish leader spoke at the entrance of the first EU leaders' retreat, an initiative created by European Council President António Costa for more informal debates. I totally agree with Americans that the region of the far north, the Arctic region, is increasingly important when we talk about defense and security and dissuasion, and it is possible to find a way to ensure a stronger [United States] footprint in Granelândia, where they are already, ”said Mette Frederiksen. The head of the Copenhagen government also recalled that Danish troops fought alongside the US for many decades. US President Donald Trump has claimed greater access to the Arctic and expressed the interest of acquiring Granelândia, an autonomous territory managed by Denmark.

item.title: USA | Trump will impose rates on “very soon” European products
item.description: United States President Donald Trump said European products will be subject to “very soon” customs rates following the imposition of tariffs on the importation of products from Canada, Mexico and China. “They are really enjoying us, we have a $ 300 billion deficit. They do not take our cars or our agricultural products, practically nothing, and we all bought millions of cars, huge levels of agricultural products, ”he said on Sunday to the press. The European Union lamented on the same day the increase in customs rates by the United States of America about products from Canada, Mexico and China, and said it will retaliate strongly if it is targeted by unfair tariffs. "The EU firmly believes that low customs rights promote economic growth and stability," the European Commission in a statement said through which he considered the imposition of more US tariffs as "harmful to all parties." If the European bloc is also the target of these measures, the community executive will “retaliate strongly”. Donald Trump signed on Saturday the executive order to apply customs rates to products from Canada, Mexico and China. The signature, which officializes the decision that had already been announced, determines the imposition of 10 percent rates to China, 25 percent to Mexico and 25 percent to Canada, except in Canadian oil, which will have a tariff of 10 by one hundred. Trump had threatened the imposition of tariffs to ensure greater cooperation from countries to prevent illegal immigration and the smuggling of chemicals such as Fentanil, an opioid that is causing important additions in the United States. The three countries promise to take action. Sacrifice (dis) necessary In the case of the European Union, a decision has not yet been made, but the concern is general and France defended on Sunday a "scathing response" of Europe in the face of threats of new customs tariffs by the US President. Trump admitted that the new rates can cause suffering to the American people, but has ensured that "everything will be worth it" because it will "make America big again." “Will there be suffering? item.title: Post Office | Announced Retoma of Service for the USA
item.description:
Macao Post Office resumed sending small packages and orders to the United States, but warned that new suspensions cannot be excluded due to US postal service policies
The Post Office of Macao and Hong Kong announced yesterday the resumption of sending small packages and orders to the United States after five days of suspension. In a statement, the Post Office of Macao (CTT) announced that they will accept again, from February 11, “all mail objects (…) for the United States”. In the same message as the Macao Post and Telecommunications Directorate Directorate, CTT recalled that the suspension "may have originated a correspondence, which will possibly result in delays in the delivery of shipments to the US." "Additionally, the possibility of any changes in the policies of US postal services [USPS) cannot be excluded at any time," the company warned. The Macao Post Office message was preceded by one of Hong Kong's counterpart, in which they said they had been “formally notified” by the US Postal Service that US authorities “currently do not impose additional fees on postal articles. with commodity ”. On January 5, the company said it had been notified by USPS that it could only send packages or orders that customers had registered with customs and the protection of US borders (CBP). The registration would require “the necessary import documents and the payment of fees made through a customs dispatcher,” added the Hong Kong Post Office. After the suspension of shipping, the company “continued to negotiate” with USPS and “can temporarily resume” the postal service for the United States. Temporary suspensions On February 4, USPS announced that it would temporarily stop accepting orders from China and Hong Kong (without any reference to Macao) “up to new order”. But hours later, USPS reversed the decision without justifying, just stating that it was going to work with the CBP to implement a collection process for the new rates imposed on Chinese goods in order to avoid interruptions in delivery. The new US President Donald Trump increased customs rates on China's imports at 10 percent after retreating in the plans to charge Canada and Mexico. The vast majority of goods sent from China arrive outside the mail system, but Trump's order specifically eliminated a tariff exemption for low -value products, purchased directly by consumers and sent through postal service. This exemption covered articles of less than US $ 800. The USPS measurement could block or delay orders made through Chinese e -commerce platforms Shein and Temu.

Since the start of the pilot project, IAS has widened the range of recipients of support, starting with permanent bedrooms who cannot rise or sit without help and with intellectual disabilities, without grade attributed, severe or deep. Later, it was extended to autistic people and people with motor disabilities. Three years after the pilot project began, the caregiver allowance was permanent. In Macao there are 13 social equipment that welcomes disabled people, with about 1,060 vacancies, volume that Hon Wai considers “to satisfy the needs of the services concerned”.

item.title: Australia interdicts social networks to children under 16 (II)
item.description:
Last week, we mentioned that the Australian Parliament approved the amendment to the “Internet Security Law (minimum age for access to social networks) on November 28, 2024, interdicting access from under 16 to most networks. The content of the law is simple, but from the point of view of its operation, there are several issues that deserve to be debated. First of all, Australia is not the first country to legislate this matter. In Europe, many countries have already restricted children's access to social networks. The established minimum age varies from country to country, but usually between 13 and 17 years old. Secondly, in Florida, the United States, the restriction of access from children under 13 to social networks triggered a process by limiting freedom of expression. The same may happen in Australia after the implementation of the new law and this will be a risk that the Australian government will have to run. Third, when one identifies a minor that transgresses the law, only the company that manages the social network is punished. The minor and parents are not considered responsible. In this sense, the law fails as a disciplinary. This approach can lead to conflicts around the assignment of liability when it comes into force. Some question whether this means to blame for social networks, ignoring the pedagogical responsibilities of families. There may be two reasons why the new law does not criminally responsible for infrastructors. First, as social networks are very popular, people generally use them, and those under 16 are easily influenced. Second, laws may predict different minimum ages for infrastructors to assume criminal liability. In Australia, the age of criminal liability is between 10 and 14 years, which means that certain transgressors aged between 10 and 14 may assume a certain degree of criminal responsibility. The new law increases the age of criminality in two years, apparently to allow users under 16 to avoid being held responsible and to prevent more children from breaking the law due to their tender age. But, on the other hand, if we only punish social networking companies that provide the tools for children to violate the law, the responsibility will only fall into these companies? Isn't this a way to put the car ahead of the oxen? In Australia, there is a new law in force to which social networking companies have to obey. However, in countries where there is no restrictions on the use of social networks by children, personal technology companies may consider establishing some restrictions to deny minors access to these networks. For example, Tiktok, Facebook and Snapchat have stipulated the minimum age of 13 years for their users. The restrictions imposed by these companies can benefit their image and reduce criticism from children's access permission to networks. Industry self-regulation is an effective way to reduce the impact of social networks on children. Fourthly, the new law requires social networking companies to take measures to verify the age of users. There are currently three viable methods of age verification: biometric analysis, online activities verification and identity document verification. Biometric analysis implies that users send a photo to the platform for the software to determine their age. It is not known if the photo will be eliminated after the age determination process is completed. Online activity verification requires users to provide their email account and, from there, an analysis will be based on the accounts related to the account. Verification of identity documents is another possibility of determining the age of users. It is unlikely to be accurately evaluated whether a user is over 16 years old based on photos or based on his online activity. However, the new law clearly stipulates that users cannot carry identity documents on social network companies' platforms, which will make the process of determining their age difficult. If the three age determination methods have problems, it is questionable that the new law can be implemented without startles. No wonder the goal, the mother company of Alphabet's Google, Facebook and Instagram, has declared in a presentation in the Australian parliament that expects the new law to be postponed until the age test will be completed. A goal spokesman said Facebook respects Australian law, but is concerned about the process in which they have rushed to pass legislation to ensure an age of access to social networks, but ignoring the opinions of others. Next week we continue our analysis.
